Title: How is the Integral of $\int_a^bf(x)~dx=\int_a^bf(a+b-x)~dx$
Content: Can Some one tell me what this method is called and how it works With a detailed proof $$\int_a^bf(x)~dx=\int_a^bf(a+b-x)~dx$$ I've been using this a lot in definite integration but haven't seemed to have realized why it is true.  But whatever it is it always seems to work. Basically a proof of how it is always true.
AcceptedAnswer: Here is a pictorial argument. $\displaystyle \int_a^b f(x) dx$ is the area under the curve $y=f(x)$ in the interval $(a,b)$ when you integrate from left to right. $\displaystyle \int_a^b f(a+b-x) dx$ is the area under the curve $y=f(x)$ in the interval $(a,b)$ when you integrate from right to left. Hence, both are equal.
